thread.title: Why Seven prefers AFL to NRL
thread.title_full: Why Seven prefers AFL to NRL | afr.com

author: Dominic White
title: Why Seven prefers AFL to NRL
text:
Seven chief Tim Worner says the 30 seconds after a goal (in AFL) is "the most valuable screen real estate on Australian television." Getty Images "They are very different games in terms of television product, you can't really compare with two and that's why we are very happy to have secured the deal for what we have."
Seven, which owns the top-rated metropolitan television network as well as Pacific Magazines and West Australian Newspapers, agreed to pay $840 million in cash and $60 million worth of advertising to secure 3.5 AFL matches per round for its free-to-air TV channel. The six-year deal will begin in 2017.
Mr Worner put the uplift on Seven's current deal with the NRL at around 50 per cent, versus the 70 per cent some analysts had predicted. Seven shares, which are near to historic lows, were 1 per cent higher at 82.2 cents at 12.44pm.
News Corp is paying about $1.3 billion of the record $2.51 billion deal struck with the Australian Football League, with Telstra paying $300 million for digital rights.
 Channel Nine inked a $925 million five-year deal with the NRL last week. Getty Images
